user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z:
```c
static size_t
get_rq_param_unquoted_copy_z (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *param, char *buf)
{
  size_t len;
  mhd_assert (NULL != param->value.str);
  if (! param->quoted)
  {
    memcpy (buf, param->value.str, param->value.len);
    buf [param->value.len] = 0;
    return param->value.len;
  }

  len = MHD_str_unquote (param->value.str, param->value.len, buf);
  mhd_assert (0 != len);
  mhd_assert (len < param->value.len);
  buf[len] = 0;
  return len;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (len < param->value.len);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No reachable-code violation: the mhd_assert(len < param->value.len) is a runtime assertion placed on a value computed just before the assertion. It does not introduce unreachable code — it can be executed when the function runs (for quoted params) and, if the condition fails at runtime, the assertion handler may abort, but that does not make any source statement statically unreachable. (Only if some external knowledge proved the condition always false or always true at compile time and code paths were eliminated would there be unreachable code; nothing in the fragment shows that.)
